chunks.original_text: 遭离凶害，大疮以疹，断骨以续，百节九窍，皆得所欲。 但以寝寐之顷，尚得安宁，况体道忘怀，故常适。 夫以一人之身，去心则危者复宁，用心则安者将亡，而况乎奉道德、顺神明、承天心、养群生者哉。 养群生弥须无心以宁也。 是以圣人建无身之身，怀无心之心，有无有之有，托无存之存，上含道德之化，下包万民之心。 圣人无心，以百姓心为心者也。 无恶无好，无爱无憎，不与凶人为雠，不与吉人为亲，不与诚人为媾，不与诈人为怨。 载之如地，覆之如天，明之如日，化之如神。 夫人之迷也，其日固久。 乍令不善者，岂造次而易哉。 必先优之柔之，使自求之，浸之润之，使自得之，然后始可长其明而成其信，悦其意而变其心。 故云载之如地，覆之如天，明之如日，化之如神。 物无小大，视之如身，为之未有，治之未然，绝祸之首，起福之元。 杜渐防萌，遏恶扬善也。 去我情欲，取民所安； 去我智虑，归之自然。 自然令物得安，使百姓日用不知也。 动之以和，导之以冲，上含道德之意，下得神明之心，光动天地，德连万民。 民无赋役，主无职负，俱得其性，皆有其神，视无所见，听无所闻，遗精忘志，以主为心。 主能体道，以道覆人，人得主恩，若自其心。 心从主后，若子归母，俯仰卧起，皆与为市者也。 与之俯仰，与之浮沉，随之外起，放之屈伸，不言而天下应，不为而万物存，四海之内，无有号令，皆变其心。 善者至於大善，日深以明，恶者性变，浸以平和。 所谓不善者，吾亦善之，所以得善也。 信者大信，至於无私，伪者情变#1，日以至诚。 不信者，吾亦信之，得信也。 残贼反善，邪伪反真，善恶信否，皆归自然。 夫指归所以屡归指於自然者，明至道之体湛然独立，自古固存，其能然於众物，而众物不能然之，故谓之自然。 非言虫鸟之分，以为至极。 夫有体此自然之道者，则能同光尘，不立圭角，使物自化，悉归於善，进其独志，若性自然。 所谓圣人不言而饮人以和。 当此之时，溷沉太虚，沾溺至和，民忘心意，芒洋浮游，失其所恶而获其所求，与天进退，与道周流，非迫禁而去恶，非拘教而后移也。 无为为之，而变化不自知也。 夫何故哉？ 世主之化，虚无寂寞，容如枯槁，心如橐钥，志如江海，施如溪谷，不别东西，不异南北，不辩甘苦，不嫌白黑，不正方圆，不定曲直，详於玄妙，务自隐匿。 所谓圣人惵惵，为天下皆浑其心也。 与物无治，浮游无极，废我之所欲为，裹天之所欲得，万物纷纷，皆注其耳目。 所谓百姓皆注耳目。 世主无为，涣如俨容，天地为炉，太和为橐，神明为风，万物为铁，德为大匠，道为工作，天下青青，靡不润泽。 圣人含如此之功用，所以能利物无穷矣。 故能陶冶民心，变化时俗，上无不包，下无不克，成遂万物，无不斟酌，感动群生，振骇八极。 天下芒芒，不识美恶，玄效昧象，自成法式。 圣人皆骇动万物，以归於道，随其所宜而成法式也。 出生人死章 出生入死，去无为也。 生之徒十有三，虚无和也，死之徒十有三实有过也，而民生有其生也动之死地为利名也十有三趋坚强也。 夫何故？ 以其生生之厚亡其生也。
chunks.translated_text:
When calamity and harm befall,
great sores erupt as rashes,
broken bones are set and bound,
every joint and orifice
fulfills its natural desire.

Yet even in slumber,
one still finds fleeting peace—
how much more so when
one embodies the Dao and forgets the self,
ever at ease.

For with a single body,
to abandon thought is to turn peril into safety,
to employ thought is to risk losing what is secure—
how much more so for those
who uphold virtue and Dao,
align with the numinous and bright,
follow Heaven’s intent,
and nurture all living beings?

Nurturing all living beings
requires above all a tranquil mind.

Thus, the Sage establishes
a body without a body,
a heart without a heart,
a presence within absence,
a trust in what is not stored—
above, encompassing the transformation of virtue and Dao,
below, embracing the hearts of all people.

The Sage has no heart,
yet takes the hearts of the people as their own.

Neither hating nor loving,
neither favoring nor rejecting,
not feuding with the wicked,
not befriending the fortunate,
not consorting with the sincere,
not resenting the deceitful.

Bearing them as the earth bears all,
covering them as Heaven does,
illuminating them as the sun,
transforming them as the numinous.

For humanity’s delusion
has endured for ages.
To suddenly make the unvirtuous virtuous—
how could it be so swift?

One must first comfort and soften them,
let them seek it themselves,
immerse and moisten them,
let them find it themselves—
only then may their clarity grow,
their sincerity take root,
their desires align,
their hearts transform.

Thus it is said:
bear them as the earth bears all,
cover them as Heaven does,
illuminate them as the sun,
transform them as the numinous.

Whether great or small,
all things are viewed as the self.
Act before action begins,
govern before disorder arises,
cutting off misfortune at its source,
awakening fortune from its origin.

Block gradual corruption,
prevent evil’s sprouting,
suppress vice and promote virtue.

Abandon my desires,
take what brings the people ease;
abandon my scheming,
return to what is natural.

Let nature allow all things to find ease,
so the people live unaware in their daily lives.

Move them with harmony,
guide them with spontaneity,
above containing the intent of virtue and Dao,
below attaining the heart of the numinous and bright,
illuminating Heaven and Earth,
connecting virtue to all people.

The people bear no burdens,
the ruler holds no grievances,
all find their true nature,
all retain their vital essence.
Seeing nothing, hearing nothing,
forgetting their refined thoughts,
taking the ruler as their heart.

When the ruler embodies the Dao,
covering people with the Way,
the people receive the ruler’s grace
as if it were their own.

Their hearts follow the ruler,
like children returning to their mother.
Bowing, rising, resting, waking—
all move as if in a marketplace.

With them in bowing and rising,
with them in floating and sinking,
following their external stirrings,
releasing their flexing and bending—
without speaking, the world responds;
without acting, all things endure.
Within the four seas,
no commands are given,
yet all transform their hearts.

The virtuous reach great virtue,
their clarity deepening daily.
The wicked’s nature shifts,
gradually becoming serene.

So-called unvirtuous—
I also treat them with virtue,
thus they attain virtue.

The trustworthy become utterly trustworthy,
reaching beyond self-interest.
The deceitful’s nature transforms,
daily approaching sincerity.

The untrustworthy—
I also treat them with trust,
thus they attain trust.

The cruel and destructive return to virtue,
the deceitful return to truth.
Virtue and vice, trust and doubt—
all return to their natural state.

The reason the Way repeatedly returns to nature
is that the ultimate Dao stands independent and profound,
existing since antiquity.
Its power acts upon all things,
yet all things cannot act upon it—
thus it is called *natural*.

Not that insects and birds
are the ultimate measure.

Those who embody this natural Dao
can harmonize with the dust of the world,
stand without sharp edges,
let things transform of their own accord,
all returning to virtue.
Advancing their singular will,
as if by nature’s own impulse.

As the Sage says:
*"Without speaking, I nourish people with harmony."*

At such times,
the world is submerged in boundless unity,
drenched in supreme harmony.
The people forget their thoughts,
lost in a daze of floating ease,
losing what they hated,
gaining what they sought,
moving with Heaven,
flowing with the Dao—
not driven by coercion to abandon vice,
not bound by teaching to change.

Through *wuwei*, transformation occurs unknowingly.

Why is this so?
The ruler’s transformation
is empty, still, and silent,
like withered wood,
the heart like a hollowed gourd,
the will like the sea,
actions like valleys—
not distinguishing east and west,
not separating south and north,
not judging sweet and bitter,
not favoring white and black,
not enforcing square or round,
not fixing straight or crooked,
delving into the mysterious,
striving to remain hidden.

As the Sage says:
*"Awakened, awakened—
for all under Heaven, I muddle their hearts."*

Without governing things,
floating without end,
abandoning what I would do,
embracing what Heaven would gain,
all things in tumult—
all pour into their ears and eyes.

As the Sage says:
*"The people all pour into their ears and eyes."*

The ruler’s *wuwei*
is serene, composed—
Heaven and Earth as the furnace,
Great Harmony as the bellows,
the numinous as the wind,
all things as the iron,
virtue as the master craftsman,
the Dao as the work—
the world verdant and lush,
nothing left unmoistened.

The Sage contains such transformative power,
thus able to benefit all things endlessly.

Thus can they mold the people’s hearts,
transform the customs of the age,
above encompassing all,
below conquering all,
perfecting all things,
nothing left unmeasured,
stirring all living beings,
shaking the eight extremes.

The world is vast and indistinct,
unaware of good and evil,
darkly effective, obscure in form,
self-forming in law.

The Sage stirs all things,
returning them to the Dao,
following what is fitting to establish law.

---
**出生入死章**
**Birth and Death**

Birth and death,
abandoning *wuwei*.

Those who cling to life—thirteen types—
are heavy with false vitality.
Those who cling to death—thirteen types—
are burdened with excess.
Yet the people live their lives,
driven to death’s edge for profit and name—
thirteen types cling to strength.

Why is this so?
Because their obsession with life
destroys their very life.

Yet thus,

the soul and vital breath scattered—
life and death are cut short.
They strive for their bodies,
yet do not know that thought harms the body.
When they sleep,

chunks.original_text: 盖闻善摄生者畜神明也，陆行不避兕虎，虎不伤也，入军不被甲兵兵不丧也。 兕无所投其角柔弱象也，虎无所措其爪体和平也，兵无所容其刃害亡中也。 夫何故哉？ 类相应也。 以无死地无亡形也。 指归：道德，神明、清浊、太和浑同，沦而为体，万物以形。 形之所托，英英荣荣，不睹其字，号之曰生。 生之为物，不阴不阳，不可揆度，不可测量，深微不足以为称，玄妙不足以为名。 光耀恍惚，无有形声，无状无象，动静无方，游於虚寂之野，处於无有之乡，得之者存，失之者亡。 道气所传，阴阳相和，凝结成识，名之为生，而又非形非象，非阴非阳。 故云不阴不阳，处无有之乡也。 夫生之於形也，神为之蒂，精为之根，营爽为宫室，九窍为户门，聪明为侯使，情意为乘舆，魂魄为左右，血气为卒徒。 进与道推移，退与德巷舒。 不离道德而非道德。 翱翔柔弱，栖息虚无，屈伸俯仰，与时和俱。 轻死与之反#2，欲生与之仇，无以为利则不可去，有以为用则不可留。 无为则生自生，故不去有为。 欲生之则死矣，故不留。 故无为，生之宅； 有为，死之家也。 夫立则遗其身，坐则忘其心，澹如赤子，泊如无形，不视不听，不为不言，变化消息，动静无常，与道俯仰，与德浮沉，与神合体，与和屈伸。 不贱为物，不贵为人，与王侯异利，与万姓殊患，死生为一，故不别存亡，此治身之无为也。 春生夏长，秋收冬藏，奉主之法，顺天之命，内慈父母，外绝名利，不思不虑，不与不求，独往独来，体和袭顺，辞让於入，不与时争，此治家之无为。 尊天敬地，不敢亡先，修身正法，去己任人，审实定名，顺物和神，参伍左右，前后相连，随时循理，曲因其当，万物并作，归之自然，此治国之无为也。 冠无有，被无形，抱空虚，履天地，驰阴阳，骋五行，从群物，涉玄冥，游乎无功，归乎无名，此治天下之无为也。 凡无为者皆生之徒。 贪生利寿，唯恐不得，强藏心意，闭塞耳目，导引翔步，动摇百节，吐故纳新，吹煦呼吸，被服五星，饮食日月，形神并作，未尝休息，此治身之有为也。 废释天时，独任人事，贱强求贵，贫强求富，饥名渴势，心常载求，衣食奢泰，事过其务，此治家之有为也。 富国兼壤，轻战乐兵，底威起节，名显势隆，刑严罚峻#3，峭直刻深，法察网周，操毒少恩#4，诸侯畏忌，常为俊雄，公强求伯，伯强求王，此治国之有为也。 祖孝悌，宗仁义，修礼节，教民知饰，修治色味，以顺民心，钟鼓琴瑟，以和民志，主言臣听，主动臣随，表功厉行，开以恩厚，号令声华，使民亲附，诸事任己，百方仰朝，此治天下之有为。 凡有为者，皆死之徒。 是故虚、无、清、静、微、寡、柔、弱、卑、损、时、和、啬，凡此十三，生之徒。 此十三者，是集道之端，养神之宅，故云生之徒。 实、有、浊、扰、显、众、刚、强、高、满、过、泰、费，此十三者，死之徒也。 此十三者与道相违，与神相反，故云死之徒也。 夫何故哉？ 圣人之道，动有所因，静有所应，四支九窍，凡此十三，死生之外具也。 虚实之事，刚柔之变，死生之内数也。 故以十三言诸。 以内有十三生徒，外成四支九窍，故以言内外也。

**Chapter on Birth and Death**

Birth and death,
abandon *wuwei* [non-action].

Those who cultivate life—thirteen types—
are **empty** [虚], **without** [无], **pure** [清], **serene** [静],
**subtle** [微], **sparse** [寡], **soft** [柔],
**weak** [弱], **lowly** [卑], **self-effacing** [损],
**timely** [时], **harmonious** [和], **restrained** [啬]—
these thirteen are the **Birth** [生] types.

These thirteen,
are the **Dao/Way’s** [道] beginnings,
the **abode of the spirit** [神明].
Hence, they are called the **Birth** [生] types.

Those who cling to death—thirteen types—
are **solid** [实], **excessive** [有], **impure** [浊],
**turbulent** [扰], **manifest** [显], **abundant** [众],
**hard** [刚], **forceful** [强], **elevated** [高],
**full** [满], **extreme** [过], **profligate** [泰],
**exhaustive** [费]—
these thirteen are the **Death** [死] types.

These thirteen,
contradict the **Dao/Way** [道],
oppose the **spirit** [神].
Hence, they are called the **Death** [死] types.

Why is this so?
The **Sage’s Dao/Way** [圣人之道],
in motion has its **root** [因],
in stillness has its **response** [应].
The four limbs and nine orifices—
these thirteen are the **external** [外] **apparatus** [具] of life and death.

The matters of **emptiness** [虚] and **solidity** [实],
the changes of **hardness** [刚] and **softness** [柔],
are the **internal** [内] **counts** [数] of life and death.
Thus, thirteen are spoken of in total.

Because within are thirteen **Birth** [生] types,
and without are the four limbs and nine orifices,
thus they are spoken of as **internal** [内] and **external** [外].

---

The adept at preserving life
nurtures the **spirit** [神明].
On land, he avoids neither **rhinoceros** [兕] nor **tiger** [虎],
yet the tiger does not harm him.
Entering battle, he wears no armor nor wields weapons,
yet weapons do not strike him.

The **rhinoceros** [兕] has no place to lodge its horn—
his **body** [体] is **soft** [柔弱].
The **tiger** [虎] has no place to strike its claws—
his **form** [形] is **harmonious** [和平].
Weapons have no place to lodge their blades—
his **essence** [精] is **unharmed** [害亡中].

Why is this so?
Because **forms** [形] resonate with their kind.
He has no **place of death** [死地], no **form of loss** [亡形].
Thus, **returning to the Dao/Way** [指归]:
**Virtue/Power** [德] and **Dao/Way** [道],
**spirit** [神明], **purity** [清] and **impurity** [浊],
**Great Harmony** [太和] all **mixed** [浑同],
sinking to become **substance** [体].
All things take **form** [形] from it.

Where **form** [形] takes root,
it thrives with **luster** [英英] and **honor** [荣荣],
yet no **mark** [字] is seen.
It is called **Birth** [生].

**Birth** [生] as a **phenomenon** [物],
is neither **yin** [阴] nor **yang** [阳],
cannot be **measured** [揆度] nor **gauged** [测量],
too **profound** [深微] to be named,
too **mysterious** [玄妙] to be described.
Its **radiance** [光] is **dazzling** [耀] yet **flickering** [恍惚],
without **form** [形] or **sound** [声],
without **appearance** [状] or **image** [象].
Its **movement** [动] and **stillness** [静] have no **fixed principle** [方].
It wanders in the **wild of emptiness** [虚寂],
dwells in the **land of nonexistence** [无有].
Those who attain it **survive** [存],
those who lose it **perish** [亡].

Where the **Dao/Way’s qi** [道气] is transmitted,
**yin** [阴] and **yang** [阳] harmonize,
congealing to form **awareness** [识],
called **Birth** [生].
Yet it is neither **form** [形] nor **image** [象],
neither **yin** [阴] nor **yang** [阳].
Hence, it is said: neither **yin** [阴] nor **yang** [阳],
dwelling in the **land of nonexistence** [无有].

**Birth** [生] in relation to **form** [形],
the **spirit** [神] is its **bud** [蒂],
**essence** [精] is its **root** [根],
**vitality** [营] and **refinement** [爽] are its **palace** [宫室],
the **nine orifices** [九窍] are its **gates** [户门],
**clarity** [聪] and **intelligence** [明] are its **ministers** [侯使],
**desires** [情] and **intentions** [意] are its **carriage** [乘舆],
**soul** [魂] and **spirit** [魄] are its **attendants** [左右],
**blood** [血] and **qi** [气] are its **soldiers** [卒徒].

Advancing, he aligns with the **Dao/Way** [道],
retreating, he conforms to **virtue/power** [德].
He neither departs from nor opposes **virtue/power** [德] and **Dao/Way** [道].

Soaring and gliding in **softness** [柔弱],
resting in **emptiness** [虚无],
bending and stretching, bowing and rising,
harmonizing with the **times** [时] as they unfold.

To **lightly regard death** [轻死] is to **contradict** [反] it,
to **desire life** [欲生] is to **be its enemy** [仇].
If there is no **use** [利], it cannot be **pursued** [去],
if there is **use** [用], it cannot be **retained** [留].

To **abandon non-action** [无为] is to let **Birth** [生] arise naturally,
thus he does not **pursue non-action** [去无为].
To **desire life** [欲生] is to **invite death** [死],
thus he does not **retain it** [留].
Hence, **non-action** [无为] is the **home of Birth** [生],
while **action** [有为] is the **house of Death** [死].

To stand is to **forget one’s body** [遗其身],
to sit is to **forget one’s mind** [忘其心],
**plain as an infant** [澹如赤子],
**tranquil as formless** [泊如无形],
neither seeing nor hearing,
neither doing nor speaking.
**Transformation** [变化] and **subtle shifts** [消息]
are without **constancy** [常].
With the **Dao/Way** he bows and rises,
with **virtue/power** [德] he floats and sinks,
with the **spirit** [神] he merges in **substance** [体],
with **Harmony** [和] he bends and stretches.

He does not **debase himself for things** [贱为物],
nor **exalt himself as a man** [贵为人].
His **interests** [利] differ from those of **kings and nobles** [王侯],
his **sufferings** [患] are unlike those of the **common folk** [万姓].
**Death** [死] and **Birth** [生] are one,
thus he does not **distinguish survival and perishing** [别存亡].
This is the **non-action** [无为] of **self-cultivation** [治身].

Spring **gives rise** [生], summer **grows long** [长],
autumn **harvests** [收], winter **conceals** [藏].
He **serves the sovereign’s law** [奉主之法],
**follows Heaven’s command** [顺天之命],
**cherishes his parents within** [内慈父母],
**rejects fame and profit without** [外绝名利].
He neither **plans** [思] nor **ponder** [虑],
neither **competes** [与] nor **demands** [求].
Coming and going alone,
his **body** [体] is **harmonious** [和],
his **conduct** [袭] is **natural** [顺].
He **submits to others in speech** [辞让於入],
does not **contend with the times** [与时争].
This is the **non-action** [无为] of **household governance** [治家].

He **honors Heaven** [尊天] and **respects Earth** [敬地],
does not **dare to abandon the ancestors** [亡先].
He **cultivates himself** [修身] and **rectifies the law** [正法],
**discards self** [去己] and **trusts others** [任人].
He **verifies reality** [审实] and **establishes names** [定名],
**follows things** [顺物] and **harmonizes the spirit** [和神].
He **consults his ministers** [参伍左右],
**connects front and rear** [前后相连].
He **adapts to the times** [随时] and **follows principle** [循理],
**bends to what is fitting** [曲因其当].
All things **act in concert** [并作],
returning to **nature** [自然].
This is the **non-action** [无为] of **state governance** [治国].

**Crownless** [冠无有], **cloaked in formlessness** [被无形],
**embracing emptiness** [抱空虚], **treading Heaven and Earth** [履天地],
**galloping yin and yang** [驰阴阳], **ranging the Five Phases** [骋五行],
**following all things** [从群物], **wandering in the Mysterious** [涉玄冥],
**playing in the realm of no effort** [游乎无功],
**returning to the land of no name** [归乎无名].
This is the **non-action** [无为] of **governing all under Heaven** [治天下].

All who practice **non-action** [无为] are **Birth** [生] types.

Greedy for life and **longevity** [利寿],
fearing they may not attain it,
they **forcefully suppress** [强藏] their **heart** [心] and **intentions** [意],
**close off** [闭塞] their **ears** [耳] and **eyes** [目].
They **guide and lead** [导引] their **steps** [步],
**agitate** [动摇] their **hundred joints** [百节].
They **expel the old** [吐故] and **intake the new** [纳新],
**blow warmly** [吹煦] and **breathe deeply** [呼吸].
They **adorn themselves with the Five Stars** [被服五星],
**nourish with the Sun and Moon** [饮食日月].
Their **form** [形] and **spirit** [神] both **act** [作],
yet they **never rest** [休息].
This is the **action** [有为] of **self-cultivation** [治身].

They **neglect Heaven’s timing** [废释天时],
**solely rely on human affairs** [独任人事].
They **debase themselves** [贱强] to **pursue nobility** [求贵],
**poverty** [贫] to **pursue wealth** [求富].
They **name hunger** [饥名] and **call thirst power** [渴势],
their **heart** [心] is always **laden with seeking** [载求].
Their **clothing** [衣] and **food** [食] are **luxurious and extravagant** [奢泰],
their **undertakings** [事] exceed their **capacity** [务].
This is the **action** [有为] of **household governance** [治家].

They **amass lands** [兼壤] for their **wealthy state** [富国],
**lightly wage war** [轻战] and **take pleasure in arms** [乐兵].
They **establish threats** [底威] and **raise banners** [起节],
their **name** [名] is **displayed** [显], their **power** [势] is **exalted** [隆].
Their **punishments** [刑] are **severe** [严], their **penalties** [罚] are **harsh** [峻],
**rigid** [峭直] and **deeply engraved** [刻深].
Their **laws** [法] are **fine-meshed** [网周], their **governance** [察] is **poisonous** [操毒],
**sparse in kindness** [少恩].
The **feudal lords** [诸侯] **fear and revile** [畏忌] them,
they are **often hailed as heroes** [俊雄].
They **pursue the title of Marquis** [公强求伯],
**Marquis** [伯] to **King** [王].
This is the **action** [有为] of **state governance** [治国].

They **cherish ancestral and filial piety** [祖孝悌],
**uphold benevolence and righteousness** [宗仁义],
**refine rituals and propriety** [修礼节],
**teach the people to adorn themselves** [教民知饰].
They **cultivate** [修治] **colors** [色] and **flavors** [味]
to **please the people’s hearts** [以顺民心].
They **employ bells and drums** [钟鼓], **lutes and zithers** [琴瑟]
to **harmonize the people’s wills** [以和民志].
The **sovereign speaks** [主言], the **ministers listen** [臣听],
the **sovereign moves** [主动], the **ministers follow** [臣随].
They **display achievements** [表功] and **exert force** [厉行],
**opening with kindness** [开以恩厚],
**proclaiming orders with splendor** [号令声华],
**making the people cling** [使民亲附].
They **undertake all affairs themselves** [诸事任己],
**rely on the people in all matters** [百方仰朝].
This is the **action** [有为] of **governing all under Heaven** [治天下].

All who practice **action** [有为] are **Death** [死] types.

Hence, the thirteen **Birth** [生] types—
**emptiness** [虚], **without** [无], **purity** [清], **serenity** [静],
**subtlety** [微], **sparseness** [寡], **softness** [柔], **weakness** [弱],
**lowliness** [卑], **self-effacement** [损], **timeliness** [时],
**harmony** [和], **restraint** [啬]—
are the **Dao/Way’s** [道] beginnings,
the **abode of the spirit** [神].
Thus they are called the **Birth** [生] types.

The thirteen **Death** [死] types—
**solidity** [实], **excess** [有], **impurity** [浊],
**turbulence** [扰], **manifestness** [显], **abundance** [众],
**hardness** [刚], **strength** [强], **elevation** [高],
**fullness** [满], **excess** [过], **profligacy** [泰],
**exhaustion** [费]—
contradict the **Dao/Way** [道],

Thus they are called the **Death** [死] types.

chunks.original_text: 夫虚生充实，无生常存，清则聪达，静则内明，微生章显，寡则生众，柔生刚健，弱生坚强，卑则生高，损则生益，时则通达，和则得中，啬则有余，是谓益生。 能行此道，与天地同，为身者久，为国者长，虽欲不然，造化不听。 夫虚无清静，既将道合，能生诸有，与造化同，故虽欲不然而造化不许也。 实生空虚，有生消亡，浊则听塞，扰则失明，显则生微，众则生寡，刚生柔韏，强生弱殃，高生卑贱，满生损空，过则闭塞，泰则困穷，费则招祸，是俱不祥，有行此道，动而之穷。 此十三者，是形有之累，生祸之元，故动而之穷。 为身不久，为国不平，虽欲不然，天地不从。 有为必败，理数自然，故天地不从也。 而民皆有其生而益之不止，皆有其身而爱之不已，动归有为，智虑常起。 人之生，动之死地也。 故去虚就实，绝无依有，出清入浊，背静治扰，变微为显，化寡为众，离柔反刚，废弱兴强，损卑归高，弃损取盈，纵时造过，释和作泰，将以有为，除啬施费。 夫何故哉？ 大有其身而忘生之道也。

The **void** [虚] gives rise to **fullness** [充] and **solidity** [实],
**emptiness** [无] sustains **constancy** [常存];
**clarity** [清] brings **acuity** [聪] and **penetration** [达],
**stillness** [静] yields **inner luminosity** [内明].

**Subtlety** [微] generates **magnificence** [章] and **manifestness** [显],
**sparseness** [寡] produces **abundance** [众];
**softness** [柔] begets **hardness** [刚] and **robustness** [健],
**weakness** [弱] fosters **firmness** [坚] and **strength** [强].

**Lowliness** [卑] engenders **elevation** [高],
**depletion** [损] spawns **advantage** [益];
**timeliness** [时] ensures **permeation** [通] and **reach** [达],
**harmony** [和] achieves **moderation** [中].

**Frugality** [啬] results in **excess** [余]—
this is called **augmenting life** [益生].

Those who practice this **Dao/Way** [道],
align with **Heaven and Earth** [天地],
endure long in **the body** [为身],
prosper far in **the realm** [为国].
Though they wish otherwise,
**Creation** [造化] does not comply.

For **emptiness** [虚] and **voidness** [无] are **clarity** [清] and **stillness** [静],
and if one seeks to **unify with the Dao/Way** [合道],
they can give rise to **all things** [诸有].
Thus, though they wish otherwise,
**Creation** [造化] does not permit it.

**Solidity** [实] produces **emptiness** [空] and **voidness** [虚],
**excess** [有] leads to **consumption** [消] and **extinction** [亡];
**impurity** [浊] causes **obstruction** [塞] and **deafness** [听],
**turbulence** [扰] brings **loss of luminosity** [失明].

**Manifestness** [显] reverts to **subtlety** [微],
**abundance** [众] returns to **sparseness** [寡],
**hardness** [刚] yields **softness** [柔] and **flexibility** [韧],
**strength** [强] generates **weakness** [弱] and **calamity** [殃].

**Elevation** [高] descends to **lowliness** [卑] and **abasement** [贱],
**fullness** [满] leads to **depletion** [损] and **emptiness** [空];
**profligacy** [泰] invites **constraint** [困] and **poverty** [穷],
**exhaustion** [费] beckons **misfortune** [祸].

These thirteen—
they are the **burdens** [累] of **form** [形],
the **roots** [元] of **disaster** [祸].
Thus, when one acts in accordance with them,
they drive one to **extremity** [穷].

In **the body** [为身], they bring **short-lived endurance** [不久],
in **the realm** [为国], they cause **instability** [不平].
Though one wishes otherwise,
**Heaven and Earth** [天地] do not obey.

**Action** [有为] must meet **defeat** [败],
**natural law** [理数] is immutable—
thus **Heaven and Earth** [天地] do not comply.

Yet the people all cherish their **life** [生] and **augment it** [益] without ceasing,
all love their **bodies** [身] and **favor them** [爱] without end.
Their **movements** [动] lead to **action** [有为],
their **scheming** [智虑] constantly arises.

**Human existence** [人之生],
is the **path to Death** [动之死地].

Thus they **forsake emptiness** [虚] for **solidity** [实],
**abandon voidness** [无] for **dependence** [依有],
**leave clarity** [清] for **impurity** [浊],
**turn from stillness** [静] to **turbulence** [扰].

They **change subtlety** [微] into **manifestness** [显],
**transform sparseness** [寡] into **abundance** [众],
**reject softness** [柔] for **hardness** [刚],
**discard weakness** [弱] to **exalt strength** [强].

They **abandon lowliness** [卑] for **elevation** [高],
**forsake depletion** [损] for **fullness** [满],
**indulge excess** [过] and **create profligacy** [泰],
**release moderation** [和] to **pursue extravagance** [泰].

They **act with intent** [有为],
**discard frugality** [啬] to **spend wastefully** [施费].

Why is this so?
They **possess their bodies** [有其身] yet **forget the Dao/Way of life** [忘生之道].

chunks.original_text: 所谓死之徒也。 是故摄生之士，超然大度，卓尔远逝，不拘於俗，不系於世，损形於无境，浮神於无内，不以生为利，不以死为害，兼施无穷，物无细大，视之如身，无所憎爱，精神隆盛，福德并会，道为中主，光见於外，自然之变，感而应之，天地人物，莫之能败。 陆行则兕虎不能伤，入军则五兵不能害，非加之而不能克，投之而不能制也，神气相通，伤害之心素自为废。 夫善摄生者之为行，既无爱憎於万物，视物常若於己身，故物亦感而相应，还自亲而无恶，理数必尔。 若影随形，非以法术加形而揣据。 夫何故哉？ 声响相应，物从其类，兕虎不加无形，而五兵不系无质。 摄生之士，贼害之心亡於中，而死伤之形亦亡於外也。 所谓虎无所措其爪，兵无所容其刃，以其无死地，信不虚焉。 道生章 道生之禀物性也，德畜之授物命也，物形之品万方也，势成之遂物形也。 是以万物得以生也，尊道而贵德视宗正也。 道尊德贵高大盛也，夫莫之爵无以名也，而常自然以为性也。 道生之无不存也，德畜之无不全也，长之无不益也，育之无不宁也，成之无不终也，熟之无不然也，养之无不利也，覆之无不藏也。 生而不有不以赀也，为而不恃无所为也，长而不宰无以为也，是谓玄德德不知也。 指归：圣知之衍，不自天下，不由地出，内在於身，外在於物，督以自然，无所不通，因循效象，无所不竭。 故道虚德无，不失其心，天尊地卑，不违其节。 何则？ 以有知无，由人识物，物类之无者生有，虚者生实。 见微知着，观始睹卒，非有巧能，自然之物，圣人因之，与天周密。 是故知道以太虚之虚，无所不禀； 禀物性也。 知德以至无之无，无所不授。 授物命也。 道以无为之为，品於万方而无首； 为而不有。 德以无设之设，遂万物之形而无事。 成功不居。 故能陶性命，治情意，造志欲，化万事。 何谓性命情意志欲？ 问六者之差也。 所禀於道而成形体，万方殊类，人物、男女、圣虑、勇怯、小大、修短，仁廉、贪酷、强弱、轻重、声色、状貌、精粗、高下谓之性。 此皆禀於道，由中而出，终焉不变也。 所授於德，富贵贫贱，夭寿苦乐，有宜不宜，谓之天命。 皆受於德，自外而来，进退由我。 遭遇君父，天地之动，逆顺昌衰，存亡及我，谓之遭命。 偶然所遇，非常定也。 万物陈列，吾将有事，举错废置，取舍去就，吉凶来，祸福至，谓之随命。 随我所为而得。 因性而动，接物感寤，爱恶、好憎、惊恐、喜怒、悲乐、忧恚、进退、取与谓之情。 自性而来，不觉而至。 因命而动，生思虑，定计谋，决安危，通万事，明是非，别同异，谓之意。 缘命而动，由我所为。 因於情意，动而之外，与物相连，常有所悦，招麾祸福，功名所遂，谓之志。 性命之动，情意已出，因而自强，谓之志也。 顺性命，适情意，牵於殊类，系於万事，结而难解，谓之欲。 欲虽出乎情意，而侈於性命，不可纵。 凡此六者，皆原道德，千变万化，无有穷极，唯闻道德者能顺其则。 道则是其本，得本者，进退自由，不为情欲之所使也。 性精命高，可变可易，性粗命下，可损可益，若得根本，不滞有无。 是故天地人物含心包核，有类之属，得道以生，而道不有其德，道生之而未有。

「They are called the disciples of death.

Thus, the practitioners of **life mastery** [摄生], with their lofty and boundless Dao/Way, stand apart in grandness and transcend the mundane, soaring far beyond the world’s constraints. They do not cling to the **customs of the masses** [俗], nor are they bound by the **affairs of the world** [世]. They diminish their **form** [形] in the **boundless** [无境], and let their **spirit** [神] drift in the **void** [无内]. They do not regard life as gain, nor death as harm. Their **comprehensive cultivation** [兼施] knows no limits—all things, great or small, are seen as the self, with neither aversion nor attachment. Their **spirit and virtue/power** [精神隆盛] are vast and harmonious, their blessings and **virtue/power** [福德] converge naturally. The Dao/Way is their central sovereign, its radiance visible without. In accordance with **natural transformations** [自然之变], they respond effortlessly—nothing in heaven, earth, or all things can defeat them.

When they walk on land, **rhino-beasts and tigers** [兕虎] cannot harm them; when they enter battle, the **five weapons** [五兵] cannot wound them. No added strength can conquer them, nor can any thrown force subdue them—**their spirit and qi** [神气] are in perfect accord, and the intent to harm is already nullified within.

For those skilled in **life mastery** [摄生], their actions are such that, with no love or hate for all things, they view each thing as if it were their own body. Thus, all things respond in kind, returning affection without malice, as **natural law** [理数] must.

Like shadows following form, it is not by **skill or technique** [法术] that they manipulate form, but by its inherent nature.

Why is this so?
Because **sounds echo in response** [声响相应], and **things follow their kind** [物从其类]. **Rhino-beasts and tigers** [兕虎] cannot harm the **formless** [无形], and the **five weapons** [五兵] cannot strike the **void of substance** [无质]. The practitioners of **life mastery** [摄生] have already extinguished the **thief’s or harmer’s intent** [贼害之心] within, and the **forms of death and injury** [死伤之形] vanish without.

Thus, **tigers have no place to set their claws** [虎无所措其爪], and **weapons find no opening for their blades** [兵无所容其刃], for they possess **no ground of death** [无死地]—this truth is not hollow.

**Dao/Way generates brilliance** [道生章]
The **inherent nature** [禀] of things born from the Dao/Way,
The **virtue/power** [德] bestowed that grants life to all things.
The **forms** [物形] of all things vary in every direction,
The **fulfillment of effort** [势成] that completes their shapes.

Thus, all things attain life through this,
And those who **honor the Dao/Way and value virtue/power** [尊道贵德] are like **sages and worthies** [视宗正].
The Dao/Way is honored, virtue/power is valued—**grand and flourishing** [高大盛].
None can confer titles upon it, for its name is **constant naturalness** [常自然].
The Dao/Way’s **generation of life** [道生] leaves nothing unborn,
Its **virtue/power’s nurturing** [德畜] leaves nothing incomplete.
It **lengthens** [长] without fail,
It **nourishes** [育] without rest,
It **completes** [成] without end,
It **ripens** [熟] without error,
It **sustains** [养] without harm,
It **covers** [覆] without concealment.

To **give birth without possession** [生而不有] is to do so without **hoarding** [赀],
To **act without reliance** [为而不恃] is to do so without **intent** [所为].
To **lengthen without slaughter** [长而不宰] is to do so without **purpose** [以为].
This is called the **mysterious virtue/power** [玄德], which **virtue/power does not know** [德不知].

**Pointing to the return** [指归]:
The **sage’s wisdom** [圣知] unfolds—
Not from the **heavens and earth** [天下],
Nor by **earthly means** [地出],
But **inherent within the body** [内在於身],
And **manifest in all things** [外在於物].
Guided by **natural law** [自然], it permeates without limit.
Following **patterns and effects** [因循效象], it is inexhaustible.

Thus, the Dao/Way is **formless** [虚], virtue/power is **voidless** [无],
Yet they do not lose their **heart** [心].
Heaven is **exalted** [尊], earth is **lowly** [卑],
Yet they do not violate their **principles** [节].

Why?
Because **knowing arises from the void** [有知无],
And **human discernment follows things** [由人识物].
Things of the same **kind** [类], when **voidless** [无], give rise to **possession** [有];
The **formless** [虚] generates the **solid** [实].
To **perceive subtlety and know its manifestation** [见微知着],
To **observe beginnings and foresee endings** [观始睹卒],
Is not a matter of **clever skill** [巧能],
But the **natural workings of things** [自然之物], which the **sage follows** [圣人因之],
In **harmony with heaven** [与天周密].

Thus, **knowing the Dao/Way through its ultimate formlessness** [太虚之虚],
They **draw from nothingness** [无所不禀].
This is the **inherent nature of things** [物性].

**Understanding virtue/power through its supreme voidlessness** [至无之无],
They **bestow without limit** [无所不授].
This is the **granting of life** [授物命].

The Dao/Way **acts without possession** [无为之为],
Its **manifestation** [品] in all directions has no **beginning** [首].
To **act without possession** [为而不有].

Virtue/power **sets without attachment** [无设之设],
It **fulfills the forms of all things** [遂万物之形] without **doing** [事].
To **complete without claiming** [成功不居].

Thus, they can **refine life and destiny** [陶性命],
**Regulate feelings and thoughts** [治情意],
**Shape resolve and cravings** [造志欲],
And **transform all affairs** [化万事].

What are **life, nature, feelings, thoughts, resolve, and cravings** [性命情意志欲]?
Ask of the **differences among these six** [六者之差].

That which is **inherited from the Dao/Way** [所禀於道] and forms **body and shape** [成形体],
Varies in every direction—**all things and beings** [人物],
**Male and female** [男女], **sage’s contemplation and bold daring** [圣虑、勇怯],
**Small and great, long and short** [小大、修短],
**Kindness and meanness, greed and cruelty** [仁廉、贪酷],
**Strength and weakness, lightness and heaviness** [强弱、轻重],
**Sounds and colors, appearance and substance** [声色、状貌],
**Refinement and coarseness, high and low** [精粗、高下]—
This is called **nature** [性].
All this is **inherited from the Dao/Way** [禀於道],
Arises from within, and **never changes** [终焉不变].

That which is **bestowed by virtue/power** [所授於德],
Riches and poverty, **early death and longevity, suffering and joy** [夭寿苦乐],
Some encounters are **fitting**, others **unfitting** [有宜不宜]—
This is called **heavenly destiny** [天命].
All this is **received from virtue/power** [受於德],
Comes from without, and **progress or retreat is in my hands** [进退由我].

To **meet with rulers and parents** [遭遇君父],
The **movements of heaven and earth** [天地之动],
To **encounter fortune or misfortune** [逆顺昌衰],
To **face life or death** [存亡及我]—
This is called **encountered destiny** [遭命].
It is **fortuitous** [偶然], not **fixed** [非常定].

When **all things are arranged** [万物陈列],
And I **undertake affairs** [将有事],
To **deploy or abandon** [举错废置],
To **take or leave, approach or withdraw** [取舍去就],
When **auspicious or inauspicious events come** [吉凶来],
When **calamity or fortune arrives** [祸福至]—
This is called **following destiny** [随命].
It is **obtained by my actions** [随我所为].

To **move from nature and destiny** [因性而动],
To **interact with things and awaken** [接物感寤],
To **love or hate, like or dislike** [爱恶、好憎],
To **startle or fear, rejoice or anger** [惊恐、喜怒],
To **grieve or delight, worry or rage** [悲乐、忧恚],
To **advance or retreat, take or give** [进退、取与]—
This is called **feelings** [情].
They arise from **nature** [性], and come **unconsciously** [不觉而至].

To **act from destiny** [因命而动],
To **generate thought and deliberation** [生思虑],
To **establish plans and strategies** [定计谋],
To **judge safety and peril** [决安危],
To **understand all affairs** [通万事],
To **discern right and wrong** [明是非],
To **differentiate the same and the different** [别同异]—
This is called **thought** [意].
It moves **along with destiny** [缘命], and is **by my doing** [由我所为].

To **stem from feelings and thoughts** [因於情意],
To **move outward and connect with things** [动而之外],
To **always find delight** [与物相连，常有所悦],
To **summon fortune or misfortune** [招麾祸福],
To **accomplish fame and achievement** [功名所遂]—
This is called **resolve** [志].
The **movement of nature and destiny** [性命之动] leads to **feelings and thoughts** [情意],
And from these, **resolve is strengthened** [因而自强].

To **align with nature and destiny** [顺性命],
To **fit with feelings and thoughts** [适情意],
To **be drawn by diverse kinds** [牵於殊类],
To **be bound by all affairs** [系於万事],
To **form attachments that are hard to untie** [结而难解]—
This is called **craving** [欲].
Though **craving arises from feelings and thoughts** [出乎情意],
It **exceeds nature and destiny** [侈於性命],
And **must not be indulged** [不可纵].

All these six—**nature, destiny, feelings, thoughts, resolve, and craving** [性命情意志欲]—
Are **rooted in virtue/power and the Dao/Way** [原道德],
And **thousandfold transformations** [千变万化] know no end.
Only those who **hear of virtue/power and the Dao/Way** [闻道德者] can follow their **principles** [则].

The **Dao/Way is the principle** [则], and **those who attain the principle** [得本者]
Move freely in **advance and retreat**, unshackled by **feelings and cravings** [情欲].

**Nature is refined, destiny is high** [性精命高],
It can be **transformed or altered** [可变可易].
**Nature is coarse, destiny is low** [性粗命下],
It can be **diminished or enhanced** [可损可益].
If one **grasps the root and principle** [得根本],
They are not **stuck in possession or void** [滞有无].

Thus, **heaven, earth, and all beings** [天地人物] contain **heart and core** [含心包核],
Belonging to their **kind** [有类].
They **obtain the Dao/Way to be born** [得道以生],
Yet the Dao/Way **does not possess their virtue/power** [而道不有其德].
The Dao/Way **generates life** [道生], yet **does not claim it** [未有].」

chunks.original_text: 得一而成，而一不求其福。 万物尊而贵之，亲而忧之，而无报其德。 得至一之所成，而一无所谢，所谓理至则迭灭者也。 夫何故哉？ 道高德大，深不可言，物不能富，爵不能尊，无为为物，无以物为，非有所迫而性常自然。 无为自为於物，不为物而故为，理数必自如然，非有物使之然。 故道之为物，窥之无户，察之无门，捪之无体，象之无容，意不能尽，而言不能通，万物以生，不为之损，物皆归之，不为之盈。 上下不穷，广大无涯，消息瀛诎，不可度訾，游於秋毫，不以为少，包裹万天，不以为多，青紫光耀，不为易志，幽冥枯槁，不为变化。 所谓常也。 运行无施，无所爱好，禀授性命，无所不为。 德流万物而不可复，恩结泽缔而不可归，道德善贷且生，若橐钥之出声气，气出无穷，不可归复也。 瞻足天下而不费，成功遂事而不衰，其於万物也，岂直生之而已哉。 生之形之，设而成之，品而流之，停而就之，终而始之，先而后之。 若水之於鱼，生成终始，不可斯须离。 既托其后，又在其前，神明以处，太和以存，清以上积，浊以下凝，天以之圆，地以之方，阴得以阴，阳得以阳，日月以照，星辰以行，四时以变化，五行以相胜。 火以之热，水以之寒，草木以柔，金石以刚，味以甘苦，色以玄黄，音以高下，变以纵横，山陵以滞，风雨以行，鳞者以游，羽者以翔，兽以之走，人以聪明，殊类异族，皆以之存，变化相背，皆以之亡。 万天殊状，水土异形，习俗相违，利害不同，容貌诡谬，意欲不通，阴阳所不能及，日月所不能明，皆以之始，皆以之终。 开口张目，屈伸倾侧，俯仰之顷，喘息之间，神所经历，心意所存，恩爱所加，雌雄所化，无所不导，无所不为，生之而不以为赀，为之而不以有求，长之而无以为有。 天下迷惑，莫之能知。 窅冥寂寞，无有形质，又能生成，不等太虚，人迷既久，故不知也。 或曰：道德，天地之神明也； 天地，道德之形容也。 或谓道德是天地之用，天地是道德之体，此瓮中蠛蠓之见，衣中虮虱之知，不可以语於道也。 何以明之？ 道德包万天也。 庄子曰：夫天地有类，而道德无形，有类之徒，莫不有数，无形之物，无有穷极。 以有数之物托於无穷，若草木离土，众星离天，不足以喻焉。 而谓之不然，则是不通乎有无相包，虚实相含，犹瓜瓠之瓣，不睹区蔓之有邻也，虮虱藏於裘褐，不知都邑之多人也。 是故宇宙之外，营域之内，拘以无禁，束以无制，安危消息，无有中外，同风共指，和顺仰制，全活姣好，靡有伤败，百祥万福，道为之盖，功玄事冥，不开於世，天下莫见，为而不废。 随迎莫见，见即非真，言常不及，非常所识。 所谓玄德，德济无穷。 天下有始章 天下有始无为身也，以为天下母万物根也。 既得其母秉自然也，以知其子生事无也。 既知其子无不间也，复守其母反其先也。 没身不殆终安宁也。 塞其兑耳目冥也，闭其门口不言也，终身不勤不劳难也。 开其兑事聪明也，济其事显功名也，终身不救不可生也。 见小曰明睹未萌也，守柔曰强和为恒也。 用其光神外动也，复归其明反其内也。 无遗身殃不为大也，是谓袭常服道制也。 指归：夫道之为物，无形无状，无心无意，不忘不念，无知无识，无首无向，无为无事，虚无澹泊，恍惚清静。
chunks.translated_text:
The **One** attained brings completion,
Yet the **One** does not seek its own fortune.
All things honor and revere it,
Cherish and worry over it,
Yet it never repays their virtue/power.
Attaining the completion of the **One**,
The **One** requires no thanks—
This is called *"when principle reaches its utmost, opposites vanish."*

Why is this so?
The **Dao/Way** is lofty and its virtue/power vast,
Deep beyond words—
Things cannot enrich it,
Titles cannot exalt it.
It acts without doing,
Yet all things act through it.
It is not forced by anything,
Yet nature remains ever spontaneous.

It acts without acting toward things,
Yet things act through it without contrivance—
Principle and law move as they must,
Not compelled by things to do so.

Thus, the **Dao/Way** as a thing:
Looked upon, it has no door,
Examined, it has no gate,
Probed, it has no form,
Mapped, it has no shape.
Mind cannot exhaust it,
Speech cannot convey it.
All things are born through it,
Yet it is not diminished by them.
All things return to it,
Yet it is not filled by them.

Above and below, it knows no end,
Broad and vast without boundary.
Ebbing and flowing, curving and bending—
Its measure cannot be fathomed.
It plays in the autumn hair’s breadth,
Yet is not deemed small;
It encompasses all heavens,
Yet is not deemed great.
Its radiance shines like emerald and purple,
Yet it does not alter its resolve.
In darkness and decay,
It does not change its nature—
This is called **constancy**.

It moves without exertion,
Holds no favorites.
It bestows nature and destiny,
Yet does nothing in particular.

Its virtue/power flows through all things,
Yet cannot be reclaimed;
Its grace binds and its blessings endure,
Yet cannot be returned.
**Dao/Way** and virtue/power lend and give birth,
Like the sound of a *tuóluò* flute—
Qi issues forth endlessly,
Never to be recovered.

It gazes upon all under heaven without depletion,
Achieves and completes without exhaustion.
Toward all things, does it merely give life?
It shapes them, establishes them, arranges them into ranks,
Stops them to perfect them,
Ends them to begin anew,
Leads them to follow or precede.

Like water to fish—
Life, form, beginning, and end,
Never parting for an instant.
It both follows and precedes,
With spirit dwelling within,
Great Harmony preserved.
The clear ascends to accumulate,
The turbid descends to congeal.
Heaven is round through it,
Earth is square through it.
Yin finds its yin,
Yang finds its yang.
Sun and moon shine through it,
Stars move through it.
The four seasons transform through it,
The Five Phases overcome one another through it.

Fire burns through it,
Water chills through it.
Grasses and trees bend through it,
Metals and stones harden through it.
Flavors are sweet or bitter through it,
Colors are dark or bright through it.
Sounds rise or fall through it,
Changes stretch or contract through it.
Mountains and hills stagnate through it,
Winds and rains move through it.
Scaled creatures swim through it,
Feathered creatures fly through it.
Beasts run through it,
Humans gain wisdom through it.
Diverse kinds and races all exist through it,
Yet perish when they oppose its transformations.

All heavens differ in form,
Waters and lands vary in shape,
Customs clash, benefits and harms diverge,
Appearance and desire are deceptive,
Intentions and cravings are incomprehensible.
Even yin and yang cannot reach them,
Sun and moon cannot illuminate them—
All begin and end through it.

Opening the mouth, stretching the eyes,
Bending, tilting, bowing, or rising—
In the space of a breath,
In the space of inhaling and exhaling,
Where spirit traverses,
Where mind and intention dwell,
Where love and attraction take hold,
Where male and female transform—
It guides all things,
Does all things,
Gives life without claiming reward,
Acts without demanding return,
Nurtures without possession.

All under heaven is bewildered,
None can know it.
Dark and silent, formless and empty,
Yet it gives birth and completes—
Not like the boundless void,
For long has humanity been deluded,
Thus they do not recognize it.

Some say:
**"Dao/Way** is the divine mystery of heaven and earth;
Heaven and earth are the manifestation of **Dao/Way**."

Others claim:
**"Dao/Way** is the function of heaven and earth,
Heaven and earth are the substance of **Dao/Way**."
This is the shortsightedness of a gnat in a jar,
The limited wisdom of lice in clothing—
Unfit to speak of the **Dao/Way**.

How may this be made clear?
**Dao/Way** encompasses all heavens.
Zhuangzi said:
*"Heaven and earth have their kinds,
Yet **Dao/Way** has no form.
Things with kinds all have limits,
Things without form know no end.*
To entrust the limited to the boundless
Is like grasses and trees torn from the earth,
Or stars torn from the sky—
Insufficient to illustrate it.

Yet to say otherwise
Is to fail to grasp
How having and not-having embrace,
How emptiness and reality contain each other—
Like the rind of a gourd,
Unaware of the tendrils’ neighboring growth,
Or lice hiding in fur,
Unaware of the multitude in the city.

Thus, beyond the cosmos yet within its domain,
Unconstrained by any prohibition,
Bound by no regulation—
Safety and peril, ebb and flow,
Know no inside or outside.
All follow the same wind,
Point in the same direction,
Harmonious and obedient to its decree,
Perfect and unblemished,
Without flaw or ruin.
Ten thousand blessings abound—
**Dao/Way** covers them all.
Its deeds are mysterious, its work hidden,
Unrevealed to the world.
All under heaven sees it not,
Yet it never ceases to act.

It responds without being seen—
If seen, it is not true.
Its constant speech never reaches,
Its extraordinary nature cannot be recognized.
This is called **mysterious virtue/power**,
Virtue/power that aids without end.

---
**The Beginning of All Under Heaven**
All under heaven has a **beginning**—
A **non-doing body** that is the mother of all things,
The root of ten thousand beings.
Having obtained its mother,
It holds to spontaneity—
Thus it knows its offspring:
All things arise without intervention.
Having known its offspring,
It never strays—
Thus it returns to its mother,
Reverting to its origin.
Death does not bring peril,
Life ends in tranquility.

Seal its senses—
Eyes and ears are darkened,
Its doors and openings are closed—
No speech all its life,
No toil or labor—
This is ease.

Open its senses—
Ears and eyes are sharp,
Its affairs are accomplished,
Its fame and deeds are manifest—
Yet its life is unsalvageable.

Seeing the small is called **clarity**—
Perceiving what has not yet sprouted.
Holding to softness is called **strength**—
Harmony as constancy.

Using its light—
Spirit moves outward,
Returning to its clarity—
Spirit moves inward.
No harm befalls the body—
This is not greatness,
But donning the **Dao/Way’s** ordinary garb,
Following its decrees.

---
**Pointing to the Return:**
The **Dao/Way** as a thing—
Formless, shapeless,
Without mind or intention,
Yet never forgets or ponders,
Without knowledge or awareness,
Without head or direction,
Without action or deed,
Empty, insubstantial, serene and still,
Vague, hazy, pure and tranquil.

chunks.original_text: 其为化也，变於不变，动於不动，反以生覆，覆以生反，有以生无，无以生有，反覆相因，自然是守，无为为之，万物兴矣，无事事之，万物遂矣。 是故无为者，道之身体，而天地之始也。 所谓天下有始。 无为微妙，周以密矣； 滑淖安静，无不制矣； 生息聪明，巧利察矣； 通达万方，无不溉矣。 故曰有为之元，万事之母也。 以为天下母也。 圣人得之，与物反矣。 既得其子。 故能达道之心，通天之理，生为之元，开事之户，因万方之知，穷众口之辫，尽异端之巧，竭百家之使。 万方之知，百家之伎，皆从道生，故称子也。 夫得道圆通，不唯独善，随机应感，妙用无方。 无方之用，运物归道，故云既知其子，复守其母。 且道人事，与时化转，因之修之，终而复始，变化忽然，通神使鬼，形於无形，事无不理，穷於无穷，极乎无有，以能雕琢，复反其母。 复守其母。 既覆又反，为天下本，游於玄冥，终身不殆。 没身不殆。 故能塞其聪明，闭其天门，关之以舌，键之以心，非时不动，非和不然，国家长久，终身无患。 塞其兑，闭其门也。 夫何故哉？ 不听之闻与天同聪，不视之见与天同明，不言之化与天同德，不为之事与天同功。 所守者要，所然者详，道德之明不蔽，而天地之虑达通。 故能响应影随，照物不穷，为福元始，为化祖宗，周流蔓延，沦於大中，身存物顺，天下不勤。 得道之用，用未常用，若影响之於形声，故终身不勤。 故力视损明，力听损聪，疾言沮德，巧伪败功。 是故口以大开，耳目急张，知故并起，万物孳蕃，奋心扬虑，显遂功名。 名成功遂，祸至福终，动罗天网#5，静陷地殃，神明不能佑，造化不能生，庶人没命，国家以丧。 开其兑，济其事，不体道而有为，故终身不救。 是以圣人退为之为，去事之事，体道之心，履德之意，统无穷之机，秉自然之要，翔於未元，集於玄妙，聪作未闻，明作未见，萌芽未动，朕圻未判，昭然独睹，无形之变，通於无表，达於无境，毫毛之恶不得生，赫赫之患不得至，见小曰明，故恶止善行也。 为之行之，绝言灭虑，积柔体弱，反於无识，诛暴救寡，与神同化，无敌之不胜，无事之不为，知力不得加，天下不能谋。 守柔曰强也。 治人理物，与阴阳配，内用其光，而外不违。 衣食耕获，桑织有余，福积祸消，人给家赡#6，心不载求，贱不望贵，贫不幸富，纤微尊俭，内外不过，奉上养下，人道尽备。 用其外光，复归内明。 复归其内，神明不耗，盘积固畜，不敢以为智。

「Its transformations unfold—
Change within the unchanging,
Motion within the still,
Returning to give birth to cover,
Covering to return to give birth,
Having to birth nothingness,
Nothingness to birth having,
Return and cover interwoven,
Naturally holding fast—
Acting without action, all things flourish,
Not acting yet all things succeed.

Thus, the **Dao/Way’s** embodiment of *wuwei* (無為),
Is the origin of heaven and earth.
So it is said, "Heaven and earth have a beginning."

*Wuwei* is subtle and profound,
Encompassing all in secrecy;
Smooth and tranquil, yet nothing escapes its sway.
Life and growth are keen and bright,
Skillful and discerning—
Reaching all corners, yet none remain untouched.
Therefore, it is said: "The origin of all things,
Is the mother of ten thousand affairs."
This is the mother of all under heaven.

The sage attains it,
And reverses with all things.
Having obtained its child,
Thus able to grasp the **Dao/Way’s** essence,
To penetrate heaven’s principles,
To birth as its origin,
To open the gate of affairs,
To harness all knowledge of ten thousand realms,
To exhaust the tongues of the multitude,
To exhaust the cunning of divergent schools,
To drain the arts of a hundred families.

All knowledge of ten thousand realms,
The arts of a hundred families,
All spring from the **Dao/Way**, hence called its child.
Attaining the **Dao/Way’s** perfect harmony,
Not only does one cultivate virtue alone,
But responds to every situation with effortless skill—
Wondrous uses without measure.
Without measure in its use,
It guides all things back to the **Dao/Way**,
Hence it is said: "Having known its child,
One again guards its mother."

Moreover, the **Dao/Way** adapts to human affairs,
Turning with the times’ transformations,
Nurturing and refining it,
Ending to begin anew,
Sudden in its changes,
Penetrating spirits, commanding ghosts,
Manifest in the formless,
No matter unaddressed,
Exhausting the inexhaustible,
Reaching the unreachable—
Yet through it all, one carves and refines,
Returning to guard its mother.

Return and guard its mother,
The root of all under heaven,
Roaming in the mysterious depths,
A lifetime without peril.
Perishing yet without peril.

Thus the sage can:
Plug his ears to preserve clarity,
Close his eyes to preserve insight,
Silence speech to preserve virtue,
Abandon deeds to preserve efficacy—
Hearing without listening aligns with heaven’s acuity,
Seeing without gazing aligns with heaven’s brilliance,
Transforming without words aligns with heaven’s **virtue/power** (德),
Acting without striving aligns with heaven’s function.

What is guarded is essential,
What is cultivated is thorough.
The **Dao/Way’s** luminous virtue is never obscured,
And heaven and earth’s concerns are fully realized.

Thus one can echo and shadow,
Illumine without end,
As the origin of blessings,
As the ancestor of transformations—
Flowing through all, permeating the great middle,
Things follow in accord, the world without toil.
The **Dao/Way’s** use is never exhausted,
Like echoes and shadows to form and sound—
Thus a lifetime without toil.

Therefore, straining eyes harms clarity,
Forcing ears harms acuity,
Hasty speech undermines virtue,
Cunning deceit ruins efficacy.
Thus, with mouth wide open,
Eyes and ears stretched taut,
Knowledge and perception arise,
All things multiply and thrive,
Stirring the heart, raising thoughts—
Fame and deeds are accomplished.
Fame and deeds accomplished,
Calamity arrives, blessings end,
Motion triggers the **Heavenly Net** (羅天網),
Stillness invites the **Earthly Retribution** (地殃),
Spirits and **Dao/Way** cannot aid,
Creation cannot sustain—
Common folk lose their lives,
States perish in ruin.

Opening its senses,
Accomplishing its affairs,
Not embodying the **Dao/Way** yet acting—
Thus its life is unsalvageable.

Hence the sage withdraws from deeds,
Abandons affairs,
Embodies the **Dao/Way’s** heart,
Follows **virtue/power** (德) with intention,
Unites the boundless mechanisms,
Holds the essentials of nature—
Soaring before the origin,
Gathering in the profound,
Clarity acts as if unheard,
Insight as if unseen,
Sprouts and seeds undisturbed,
The subtle threads uncut—
Brightly perceiving alone,
The changes of the formless,
Penetrating the unexpressed,
Reaching the limitless—
Not even the slightest evil can arise,
Not even the greatest calamity can approach.
Seeing the small is called **clarity**—
Thus evil ceases, good prevails.

Acting and refining,
Cutting off speech, extinguishing thought,
Accumulating softness, embodying weakness,
Returning to the state of no awareness—
Punishing violence, aiding the few,
Aligning with the divine transformations,
The unconquerable is conquered,
The unattainable is achieved,
Strength cannot be added,
All under heaven cannot scheme.
Holding to softness is called **strength**.

Governing people, managing things,
In harmony with yin and yang,
Internally using its light,
Yet externally causing no offense—
Clothing, food, tilling, and harvest,
Silk weaving with abundance,
Blessings accumulate, misfortunes dissolve,
People are provided, households are supported,
The heart does not bear the weight of seeking,
The humble do not aspire to the noble,
The poor do not envy the rich,
The refined honor simplicity,
Within and without, nothing is excessive—
Serving above, nourishing below,
Human ways fully realized.

Using its external light,
Returning to its internal **clarity**,
Returning to its internal **clarity**—
Spirit and insight are never depleted,
Stored like a coiled serpent, firmly held,
Daring not to call it wisdom.

---」

chunks.original_text: 如江海与天同虑，绝灭三五，害之以事，填而塞之，使不可识。 为瘴为聋，与天地同，为玄为默，与道穷极，去必离咎，违患废贼，浮德载和，无所不克。 无遗身殃故也。 故人能入道，道亦入人，我道相入，沦而为一。 守静致虚，我为道室，与物俱然，浑沌周密，反初归始，道为我袭。 袭，重累也。 与常道合德，若累衣於身，故云道为我袭，是为袭常者也。 行於大道章 使我介然有知操有明也，行於大道修正常也，唯施是畏恐蹉跌也。 大道甚夷广易平也，而民好径乐妄行也。 朝甚除宅美大也，田甚芜生众秽也，仓甚虚农业废也，服文采五色会也，带利剑任伐杀也，厌饮食常饱醉也，财货有余货殖实也。 是谓盗夸暴藏外也，非道哉与天戾也。 指归：道德不为智巧，故能陶冶天地，造化阴阳，而天地不能欺也。 天地不为知巧，故能含吐变化，杀生群类，而万物不能逃也。 道释自然而为知巧，则身不能自存，而何天地之所能造，阴阳之所能然也。 天地释自然而为知巧，则身不能自生，而何变化之所包，何万物之所能全。 此所谓自然者，如水自然润下，火自然炎上，性分之内，亦非有为。 故虚无无为、无知无欲者，道德之心而天地之意也。 清静效象、无为因应者，道德之动而天地之化也。 道德因应，天地动化，若像中之象，空中之响，不足为难也。 何以明之？ 庄子曰：道之所生，天之所兴，始始於不始，生生於不生，存存於不存，亡亡於不亡。 不始不生，不存不亡者，道德之元也。 凡此数者，自然之验，变化之常也。 故人之动作不顺於道者，道不佑也； 不顺於德者，德不助也； 不顺於天者，天不覆也； 不顺於地者，地不载也。 夫道德之所不佑助#7，天地之所不覆载，此息祸之所不远，而福德之所不近也。 人禀气乎道德，成形乎天地，举措不顺道，自然无与安，故福德日远，祸患日近。 是以玄圣处士，负达抱通，提聪挈明，顺道奉德，弃知亡身，厉志忧畏，唯恐蹉跌。 故勉於巧不巧之巧，务於明不明之明，信顺柔弱，躬耕而食，常於止足，归乎无名，战战栗栗，恐失自然，患至天地，祸及人民。 挈然有知行於大道者，唯施是畏也。 是以吉祥之应，福德之至，如影之与形，响之应声，非有期会，动若俱生，是故大道甚夷，其化无形，若远而近，若晦而明。 平夷而无秽，要约而易行，无为而成功，无事而福盈，天地由之，万物以生。 大道甚夷平也。 而民背之，用其聪明，任伪废道，反地逆天，尊知贵巧，欺鬼侮神，饰治邪淫，归伪去真，创作改制，起事遂功。 人好径也。 丰屋荣观，大户高门，饰以其怪，加以采文，以知为本，以巧为绳。 朝甚除也。 诈为之斧，伪为之斤，秉术操数，简织贱耕，田秽不修，节莠并生，田苗不起，囷仓虚空。 田甚芜，仓甚虚。 衣重五采，锦绣玄黄，冰纨绮谷，靡鹿光辉。 服文采也。 利剑坚甲，强弩劲弓，轻车骏马，多侠凶人。 权重名显，威势流行，伐杀绝里，臣役细民，妬廉嫉让，疾忠毒信，结邪连伪，与善为怨，尚争贵武，无不侵凌，使通境外，常议弒君。 带利剑也。 食重五味，碊贼群生，刳胎杀鷇，逆天之心，居常醉饱，取求不厌。 厌饮食也。 多藏金玉，畜积如山，所有珍宝，拟於人君。
chunks.translated_text:
「Like the great rivers and seas sharing the same purpose as Heaven,
To extinguish the **Three Five**—
To harm them with affairs,
To fill and block them,
So they cannot be discerned.

As **malaria** and **deafness**,
In harmony with Heaven and Earth,
As **mysterious** and **silent**,
Exhausting the Dao,
Departing leaves no blame,
Defying calamities and ruining bandits,
Floating **virtue** laden with peace—
Nothing it cannot overcome.

Because it does not leave the body to suffer.

Thus, when a person enters the Dao,
The Dao also enters the person,
Our Dao merging within—
Submerged and unified as one.

Preserving stillness to attain **emptiness**,
I become the Dao’s dwelling,
With all things in their natural state,
Chaotic yet complete in every detail,
Returning to the origin, to the beginning—
The Dao covers me like a robe.

A robe—
Layer upon layer.

Merging with the **constant Dao** in **virtue/power**,
Like piling garments upon the body,
Hence it is said the Dao covers me,
This is the **constant Dao** that envelops me.

In the chapter *Conducting the Great Dao*:

It is I who, with knowledge and clarity,
Conduct myself in the Great Dao—
Refining the **constant Dao**,
Only fearing **Shi** lest I stumble and fall.

The Great Dao is vast and smooth,
Easy and level—
Yet people prefer narrow paths,
Delight in reckless action.

Morning is pristine, yet palaces are adorned with excess,
Fields are overgrown with weeds and pests,
Granaries are empty, agriculture neglected,
Garments flash with five colors,
Swords are worn for slaughter,
Feasts are indulged in gluttony and drunkenness,
Wealth is hoarded like mountains,
All treasures compared to a sovereign’s.

This is called **plundering, boasting, and hoarding**—
A perversion of the Dao,
A rebellion against Heaven.

**Pointing to return**:
The Dao’s **virtue/power** is not a matter of cleverness,
Thus it can mold Heaven and Earth,
Shape yin and yang,
And Heaven and Earth cannot deceive it.

Heaven and Earth do not rely on cleverness,
Thus they contain and release transformations,
Kill and give life to all beings,
And all things cannot escape them.

If the Dao **releases** and **returns** to cleverness,
Then the body cannot preserve itself,
And how could Heaven and Earth be shaped,
Or yin and yang be realized?

If Heaven and Earth **release** and **return** to cleverness,
Then the body cannot sustain itself,
And how could transformations be embraced,
Or all things be fully nurtured?

This so-called **naturalness**,
Like water naturally moistening below,
Fire naturally blazing upward—
Within their inherent nature,
It is not a matter of contrivance.

Thus, **emptiness** and **non-action**,
**non-knowledge** and **non-desire**—
The heart of **virtue/power** and the intent of Heaven and Earth.

**Clarity** and **stillness** mirroring the **form**,
**Non-action** responding to circumstances—
The movement of **virtue/power** and the transformation of Heaven and Earth.

**Virtue/power** responds to circumstances,
Heaven and Earth move and transform—
Like images within a mirror,
Echoes in empty space—
This is no difficult matter.

How does one know this?
Zhuangzi said:
*"What the Dao produces, Heaven nurtures,
Beginning without beginning,
Giving life without giving life,
Preserving without preserving,
Destroying without destroying.
That which has no beginning, no giving life,
No preserving, no destroying—
This is the origin of **virtue/power**.*

All these things,
Are the **verifications** of naturalness,
The **constants** of transformation.

Thus, when a person’s actions do not align with the Dao,
The Dao does not favor them;
When they do not align with **virtue/power**,
**Virtue/power** does not aid them;
When they do not align with Heaven,
Heaven does not shelter them;
When they do not align with Earth,
Earth does not bear them.

What the Dao does not favor,
What **virtue/power** does not aid,
What Heaven does not shelter,
What Earth does not bear—
This is where calamities linger,
And blessings never draw near.

People draw **qi** from **virtue/power**,
Take form from Heaven and Earth—
If their actions do not align with the Dao,
They naturally find no peace,
Thus blessings recede daily,
And misfortunes approach.

Therefore, the **mysterious sages** and **recluses**,
Bearing the Dao and embracing its **completeness**,
Lifting **insight** and grasping **clarity**,
Aligning with the Dao and honoring **virtue/power**,
Discarding cleverness and abandoning the body,
Grasping their resolve with dread,
Only fearing to stumble and fall.

Thus they strive for **cleverness** that is not clever,
Pursue **clarity** that is not clear,
Trust in softness and weakness,
Tilling the land for their sustenance,
Ever content with moderation,
Returning to the **nameless**,
Trembling with fear,
Lest they lose **naturalness**,
And their misfortunes extend to Heaven and Earth,
Affecting all people.

Those who, with knowledge and clarity,
Conduct themselves in the Great Dao—
Only fear **Shi**.

Thus auspicious responses and blessings arrive,
Like shadows following form,
Echoes answering sound,
Without expectation or prearrangement,
Arising as if born together—
Hence the Great Dao is vast and smooth,
Its transformation formless,
Like something distant yet near,
Like something dim yet bright.

Simple and vast without blemish,
Concise yet easy to follow,
Achieving success without contrivance,
Attaining blessings without effort—
Heaven and Earth follow it,
And all things come to life from it.

The Great Dao is vast and smooth.

Yet people turn away from it,
Using their cleverness,
Embracing deceit and neglecting the Dao,
Reversing Earth and defying Heaven,
Exalting knowledge and valuing cleverness,
Cheating spirits and mocking gods,
Adorning false governance with perversion,
Pursuing deceit while abandoning truth,
Inventing customs and altering institutions,
Creating affairs and accomplishing deeds.

People delight in narrow paths.

Palaces are grand, gates towering high,
Adorned with bizarre embellishments,
Layered with colorful patterns—
Cleverness as their foundation,
Cunning as their measure.

Morning is pristine, yet deception is their axe,
Falsehood is their adze—
Wielding schemes and manipulating numbers,
Weaving fine cloth while exploiting labor,
Neglecting fields, letting weeds and pests flourish,
Harvests failing, granaries empty.

Fields are overgrown, granaries are empty.

Garments flash with five colors,
Silks and brocades in dark yellows,
Fine linen and delicate embroidery,
Smooth as deer, radiant as phoenixes.

Wearing garments of five colors.

Sharp blades and sturdy armor,
Mighty crossbows and powerful bows,
Light chariots and swift steeds,
Many reckless and fierce warriors.

Wealth is heavy, status honored,
Power and influence prevail—
Slaughtering without restraint,
Subjugating the common folk,
Jealous of the upright, resentful of the generous,
Hating loyalty, poisoning trust,
Binding with evil, joining with falsehood,
Harming the good, nurturing enmity,
Valuing contention and martial prowess—
None they do not oppress,
Forcing borders to expand,
Ever plotting to assassinate rulers.

Wearing swords of slaughter.

Feasts overflow with five flavors,
Pests swarm in abundance,
Cutting into wombs, killing unborn—
A defiance of Heaven’s intent,
Ever drunk and gluttonous,
Taking without restraint.

Indulging in food and drink.

Hoarding gold and jade,
Piling wealth like mountains—
All treasures compared to a sovereign’s.»

chunks.original_text: 货财有余。 出入奇异，荣盛光显，离众绝俗，超然独存，乱世高之，称为大人。 是谓盗夸。 过众恶大，罪重祸深，贤父不畜，明主不臣，道所不佑，神所不在，天所不覆，万物所怨。 有人若此，丧之受祸，生之受息，身苟不获，事及子孙。 以非道故。 善建章 善建者不拔以道立也，善抱者不脱抱以德也，子孙祭祀不辍世无极也。 修之於身其德乃真#8治生息也； 修之於家治慈畜也，其德有余流相成也； 修之於乡治分职也，其德乃长无不克也； 修之於国治法则也，其德乃丰无谗贼也； 修之於天下治表式也，其德乃普宇内服也。 故以身观身知彼身也，以家观家知彼家也，以乡观乡知彼乡也，以国观国知彼国也，以天下观天下近知远也。 吾何以知其然哉？ 以此求之身也。 指归：天地之间，广大修远，殊风异俗，物类众巨，变化无穷，利害谬诡，故能不能制，而为不能为也。 我为天下，而天下亦为我，彼我相遇，则彼众而我寡，以寡遇众，则众宁而寡殆。 故以己知立则知夺之，以己巧立则巧伐之，以己力立则力威之。 唯无所为，莫能败之。 何以效其然也？ 夫默而求响，响不我应； 托阴求影，影不我从。 畏响而扣金，响愈我应； 恶影而处阳，影益我从。 由此观之，无为不能遁福，有为不能逃患。 是以圣人去力、去巧、去知、去贤，建道抱德，摄精畜神，体和袭弱，履地戴天。 善建不拔者也。 空虚寂泊，若亡若存，中外俱默，变化於玄，无为无事，反朴归真，无法无度，与变俱然。 善抱不脱。 抱小托大，牧养万民，方圆先后，常与身存，体正神宁，传嗣子孙。 子孙祭祀不绝。 德积化流，洋溢无穷，衰而复盛，与天俱终。 故治之於身，则性简情易，心达志通，远所不远，明所不明，重神爱气，轻物细名，思虑不惑，血气和平，筋骨便利，耳目聪明，肌肤润泽，面理有光，精神专固，生生青青，身体轻劲，美好难终。 修之身，其德乃真也。 治之於家，则夫信妇贞，父慈子孝，兄顺弟悌，九族和亲，耕桑时得，畜积殷殷，六畜蕃殖，事业修治，常有余财，乡邑愿之。 修之於家，其德有余。 治之於乡，则睹纲知纪，动合中和，名实正矣。 白黑分明，曲直异理，是非自得，奸邪不起，威严尊显，令行禁止，奉上化下，公若父子，敬爱信向，上下欢喜，百姓和集，官无留负，职修名荣，称为君子，常有余德，没身不殆。 修之於乡，其德乃长。 治之於国，则主明臣忠，朝不壅贤，士不妬功，邪不蔽正，谗不害公，和睦顺从，上下无怨，百官乐职，万事自然，远人怀慕，天下同风，国富民实，不伐而疆，宗庙尊显，社稷永宁，阴阳永合，祸乱不生，万物丰熟，境内大宁，邻家托命，后世蕃昌，道德有余，与天为常。 修之於国，其德乃隆。 治之於天下，则主阴臣阳，主静臣动，主圆臣方，主因臣唱，主默臣言。 正直公方，和一大通，平易无为，寂泊无声，德驰相告，神骋相传，运动无端，变化若天，不行而知，不为而成，功与道伦，宇内反真，无事无忧，太平自兴。 修之天下，其德乃普也。 是故我身者，彼身之尺寸也； 我家者，彼家之权衡也； 我乡者，彼乡之规矩也； 我国者，彼国之准绳也。 所谓以身观身，以家观家，以国观国，以天下观天下也。
chunks.translated_text:
Excess in wealth and goods.
Strange and wondrous comings and goings,
Honor and splendor radiant and bright,
Detached from the masses, severed from custom,
Standing alone in tumultuous times,
Praised as a great sage—
This is called **theft of glory**.

Exceeding the crowd in vice, great in evil,
Crimes heavy, calamities deep,
The virtuous father does not rear them,
The enlightened ruler does not employ them,
The Dao does not favor them,
The spirits do not dwell with them,
Heaven does not shelter them,
All things hold them in hatred.

If one is thus,
To lose them is to invite calamity,
To keep them is to invite ruin,
Their bodies unprotected,
Their misfortunes extending to descendants—
All through un-Dao ways.

**On Establishing Virtue Properly**
Those who establish well do not falter—
They stand firm through the Dao.
Those who embrace well do not slip—
They hold fast through virtue.
Their descendants’ sacrifices never cease—
The world knows no end.

Cultivated in the self, its virtue becomes true—
**Nurturing life and breath.**
Cultivated in the family, it governs kindness and abundance—
Its virtue overflows, benefiting kin.
Cultivated in the village, it orders roles and duties—
Its virtue endures, conquering all.
Cultivated in the state, it establishes laws and norms—
Its virtue flourishes, free from slander and treachery.
Cultivated in the world, it sets standards and models—
Its virtue is universal, all under heaven in service.

Thus, by observing the self, one knows other selves,
By observing the family, one knows other families,
By observing the village, one knows other villages,
By observing the state, one knows other states,
By observing the world, one knows the world—
Near and far revealed.

How do I know this to be true?
By seeking it within oneself.

**The Principle of Return:**
Between Heaven and Earth, vast and boundless,
Diverse winds and customs, myriad creatures great and small,
Endless transformations, benefits and harms deceitfully entwined—
Thus, the able cannot control the unable,
And the unable cannot act where the able cannot.

I act for the world, yet the world also acts for me.
When I and it meet, if I am few and it many,
To meet many with few—
The many grow secure, the few grow perilous.

Thus, if one establishes by strength, others will seize it;
If one establishes by cunning, others will counter it;
If one establishes by force, others will threaten it.
Only by doing nothing can one not be defeated.

How does this manifest?
Silent, yet seeking echoes—
Echoes do not answer me.
Trusting shadow to follow shade—
Shadow does not follow me.
Yet fearing echoes, I strike the bell—
Echoes answer louder than before.
Hating shadows, I stand in the sun—
Shadows cling to me more fiercely.

From this, it is clear:
Non-action cannot evade blessing,
Action cannot escape misfortune.

Thus, the sage abandons strength,
Abandons cunning,
Abandons knowledge,
Abandons virtue—
Establishes the Dao, embraces virtue,
Harbors essence, nurtures spirit,
Harmonizes the body, follows weakness,
Steps upon the Earth, bears Heaven.
**This is the unshaken foundation.**

Empty, still, and quiet,
As if absent yet present,
Inner and outer both silent,
Transforming in the Mysterious,
Doing nothing, yet nothing undone,
Returning to simplicity, embracing truth,
Without laws or measures,
Yet aligned with transformation.

**This is the unbroken embrace.**

Nurturing the small to sustain the great,
Tending the myriad people,
Ordering square and round, precedence and sequence,
Ever abiding with the body,
Upright in form, serene in spirit,
Transmitting lineage to descendants.
Descendants’ sacrifices never cease.

Virtue accumulates, transforming and flowing,
Endless, ebbing and swelling with Heaven.
Cultivated in the self, its virtue is true—
**Life’s vitality thrives, the body light and strong,**
Beauty enduring yet untamed.

Cultivated in the family,
Husbands trustworthy, wives chaste,
Fathers merciful, children filial,
Brothers obedient, younger siblings respectful,
Nine clans harmonious and affectionate,
Farming and silk-reeling timely,
Storehouses abundant,
Livestock thriving,
Affairs prosperous, wealth ever sufficient,
Neighbors envy their fortune.

Cultivated in the family, its virtue overflows.

Cultivated in the village,
Clear distinctions in governance,
Actions aligned with harmony,
Names and realities correct,
Black and white distinct,
Curved and straight in their nature,
Right and wrong self-evident,
No deceit arises,
Authority revered and displayed,
Orders enforced without obstruction,
Above transforming, below responding,
Public and private as father and child,
Respect and love sincere,
Superior and inferior in joy,
People united, officials without grievance,
Duties fulfilled, reputation honored,
Called *junzi*, virtue ever abundant,
Death not a peril.

Cultivated in the village, its virtue endures.

Cultivated in the state,
The ruler enlightened, ministers loyal,
No blocking of the worthy in court,
No jealousy of merit among scholars,
No obstruction of the upright by the crooked,
No slander harming the public,
Harmony and compliance above and below,
No grievances, officials delighted in their duties,
All affairs in natural order,
Distant peoples drawn in longing,
The world follows its wind,
The state rich, the people flourishing,
Borders secure without conquest,
Ancestral temples honored,
Altars and fields eternally at peace,
Yin and Yang eternally united,
No calamities arise,
All things bountiful and ripe,
The realm at great ease,
Neighbors entrust their lives,
Posterity thrives,
Virtue and Dao abundant,
Ever as Heaven’s constant.

Cultivated in the state, its virtue is exalted.

Cultivated in the world,
The ruler yin, ministers yang,
The ruler still, ministers active,
The ruler round, ministers square,
The ruler follows, ministers respond,
The ruler silent, ministers speak.
Upright and fair, harmonious and unified,
Easy and effortless, quiet and soundless,
Virtue spreads like whispers,
Spirit transmits like currents,
Movement without origin,
Transformation like Heaven,
Acting without action,
Achieving without doing,
Merit aligned with the Dao,
The world returns to truth,
No affairs, no worries,
Great Peace spontaneously arises.

Cultivated in the world, its virtue is universal.

Thus, my self is the measure of other selves,
My family the balance of other families,
My village the compass of other villages,
My state the standard of other states—
This is the meaning of:
Observing the self to know other selves,
Observing the family to know other families,
Observing the village to know other villages,
Observing the state to know other states,
Observing the world to know the world—
Near and far revealed.

The ruler is the vital core of the land;
The land is the form of the ruler.

Thus, the land and the ruler share prosperity and suffering,
Share corruption and rectitude.
When the people thrive, the land flourishes;
When the ruler is whole, the land is whole.
Families and states preserve each other,
Rulers sustain one another.
If one attains self-mastery, the land naturally follows.

Therefore, those who can know me know all;
Those who can govern me govern all;
What benefits me benefits all;
What suits me suits all.
What harms me yet benefits others—
The world knows none such.

This is the meaning of:
*"A single word sufficient for a lifetime’s practice—*
*Is it not perhaps the virtue of *rú*?"*

How do I know the world is thus?
It is by this.
It is by this.

chunks.original_text: 含德之厚章 含德之厚体道元，比於赤子柔弱虚。 毒虫不螫毒不施，攫鸟不搏害不摩，猛兽不据威不加。 骨弱筋柔脆以危，而握固据难开，未知牝牡之合不相化，而较作无为为，精之至神明多。 终日嗥而嗌不嘎音声和，和之至体道行。 知和曰常与道同，知常曰明日以聪，益生曰祥日广长，心使气曰强日坚强，物壮则老衰坚强，谓之非道体祸殃，不道早已大命丧。 指归：道德虚无，神明寂泊，清静深微，太和滑淖，听之寂寥，视之虚易，上下不穷，东西无极。 天不能裹，地不能囊，规不能圆，矩不能方，度不能度，而量不能量，金玉不能障蔽，水火不能壅落，万物莫之能领，患祸莫之能作。 况浮翱翔，浑沌磅砖，心无所栖，形无区宅，陶冶禀授，万天以作，群物得之，滋滋哑哑，知虑不能得，有为不能获，思之逾远，为之益薄，执之不我擒，纵之不我释。 唯无欲者，身为之宅，藏之於心，故曰含德。 同於德，德亦得之。 体德容深，含德之厚。 夫德之在人，犹父母之於身也； 其於万物，犹珠玉之与瓦铅也。 父母生我不可易，珠玉润我不可掷。 是以含德之士，重身而轻天下，犹慈父孝子不以其有易其邻； 大身而细物者，犹良贾察商不以珠玉易瓦铅也。 其无欲也，非恶货而好康也，天下之物莫能悦其心也。 其为虚也，非好静而恶扰也，天下之事莫足为也。 夫何故哉？ 所有重而天下轻也。 明於轻重之称，通於利害之变，故万物不能役，而天下不能傜也。 故不为虚而虚自起，不为静而静自生，不休神而神自定，不和气而气自平。 是以不听而闻无声之声，不视而见无形之形，不思而领是非之意，不虑而达同异之乡。 神沦天地，德遵阴阳，不请福而天地佑之，不辞祸而患害#1去之，不杀戮而天下畏之，不施与而天下爱之。 鼓腹而乐，俯仰而娱，食草而美，饮水而甘。 乔木之下，精神得全，岩穴之中，心意常欢#2，贫乐其业，贱忘其卑，穷而恬死，困而忘危，功与地配，德与天齐，反愚归朴，比於婴儿。 含德之厚，比於赤子。 是故建身为国，诚以赤子为容，则是天下尊道贵德，各重其身，名势为垢，万物为尘，贪夫逃爵，残贼反仁，积柔集弱，唯德是修。 而作福生乱者，有何由然。 自然同德，无由生也。 悲夫天地之道，深以远，妙以微，能识之者寡，行之者希，智惠不能得，唯赤子为体之。 赤子体似於德。 夫赤子之为物也，知而未发，通而未达，能而未动，巧而居掘，生而若死，新而若弊，为於不为，与道周密。 生不生之生，身无身之身，用无用之用，闻无闻之闻，无为无事，无意无心，不求道德，不积精神，既不思虑，又无障截，神气不作，聪明无识，柔弱虚静，魂魄无事。 乐无乐之乐，安无欲之欲，生不枉神，死不幽志。 故能被道含德，与天地同，则蜂虿虫蛇无心施其毒螫，攫鸟猛兽无意加其攫搏。 毒虫不螫，擭鸟不搏者，以无死地也。 骨弱筋柔，握持坚固，不睹牝牡，阴阳以化。 精神充实，人物并归，啼号不嗄，可谓志和，为之行之，与道为常。 知和曰常。 执之守之，时曰聪明。 知常曰明。 自然生息#3，动，合百祥。 益生日祥。 心意玄作#4，气顺坚强。 心使气曰强也。 无所为，故无所不克；
chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter on the Profound Depth of Contained Virtue**

The profound depth of contained virtue—
Its body aligns with the Dao’s origin,
Like a babe in its tender, weak, and void state.

Venomous creatures do not sting,
Raptors do not clutch,
Fierce beasts do not seize,
Nor do they add harm—
Its bones are frail, its sinews soft,
Yet its grasp is firm, its hold unyielding.
It knows not the union of male and female,
Yet the Dao’s effortless transformation is complete—
Its essence is the most divine and luminous.

All day it wails, yet its throat never grows hoarse,
Its voice remains in perfect harmony—
The harmony of the Dao is its way.

To know harmony is to know the eternal Dao,
To know the eternal Dao is to be enlightened and discerning—
Life flourishes as a blessed, boundless day,
The heart directs the *qi* to become robust and unshakable—
When things grow strong, they turn decrepit and rigid,
This is called *not* aligning with the Dao—
A fate of calamity and ruin.
To stray from the Dao means an early end to one’s great destiny.

**Explanation of the Way:**
Virtue is void and boundless,
Divine luminosity is tranquil and profound—
Pure, still, and subtly vast,
The Great Harmony flows like water.
Listen to it, and it is silent and empty,
Observe it, and it is formless and easy.
Its limits are without end, its bounds without measure—
Heaven cannot enfold it,
Earth cannot contain it,
The compass cannot make it round,
The square cannot make it square,
Measure cannot measure it,
Yet scales cannot weigh it—
Gold and jade cannot shield it,
Water and fire cannot obstruct or destroy it,
All things fail to grasp it,
Misfortune cannot befall it.

How much more so for those who float and soar,
Who are pure and vast like the primordial chaos—
Their hearts have no dwelling,
Their forms no fixed abode.
Through natural refinement and reception,
They take form from the Ten Thousand Heavens,
All beings receive it—
Nourished and content,
Yet thought cannot grasp it,
Action cannot seize it—
The farther one seeks, the thinner it becomes,
The more one clutches, the more it eludes.
To grasp it is to be caught by it,
To let go is to be released by it.

Only those without desire
Make their bodies its dwelling,
Store it within their hearts—
Thus it is called *containing virtue*.

To align with virtue is to receive virtue—
The depth of contained virtue is profound.
Virtue in a person
Is like a parent’s love for their child—
For all beings, it is like pearls and jade compared to clay and lead.
Parents give birth to me, and this cannot be changed,
Pearls and jade nourish me, and this cannot be discarded.

Thus, the virtuous person
Values their body above all else,
Yet regards the world with lightness—
Like a benevolent father and filial child,
Who would not trade their love for wealth.
The one who cherishes their body
And holds all else in slight regard
Is like a wise merchant,
Who would not exchange pearls and jade for clay and lead.

Their lack of desire is not from hating wealth or loving ease—
The world’s treasures cannot please their heart.
Their embrace of emptiness is not from loving stillness or hating disturbance—
The world’s affairs are not worth their effort.

Why is this so?
Because they hold their own nature as weighty,
And the world as light.

They understand the distinction between weight and light,
They grasp the shifts between profit and harm—
Thus all things cannot enslave them,
Nor can the world deceive them.

Therefore, they do not seek stillness, yet stillness arises,
They do not seek harmony, yet harmony is born,
They do not rest their spirit, yet the spirit finds peace,
They do not cultivate harmony, yet the *qi* becomes balanced.

Thus, they do not listen, yet hear the soundless sound,
They do not look, yet see the formless form,
They do not think, yet discern right and wrong,
They do not ponder, yet reach the realm of unity.

Their spirit permeates Heaven and Earth,
Their virtue follows Yin and Yang—
They do not pray for blessings, yet Heaven and Earth protect them,
They do not shun misfortune, yet calamities and harm depart,
They do not execute, yet all under Heaven fears them,
They do not bestow, yet all under Heaven loves them.

They find joy in a full belly,
Delight in bowing and rising,
Eat coarse grasses yet find it savory,
Drink plain water yet find it sweet.

Beneath towering trees,
Their spirit remains whole,
Within rocky caves,
Their heart ever rejoices—
The poor find joy in their work,
The lowly forget their humility,
In destitution, they meet death with serenity,
In hardship, they forget all danger.
Their deeds match the Earth’s,
Their virtue aligns with Heaven’s—
They return to simplicity, embrace naturalness,
And are like infants once more.

The profound depth of contained virtue
Is likened to the babe in its cradle.

Thus, to establish the body as the foundation of the state,
And to take the babe as the model of governance,
Then the world will honor the Dao and revere virtue,
Each will cherish their own body,
Renown and power will become stains,
All things mere dust—
The greedy will flee titles,
The cruel will turn to benevolence,
Gathering softness and weakness,
Only virtue will be cultivated.

Yet those who create blessings and sow chaos—
How could this ever arise?

It is from aligning with virtue by nature,
No cause for its generation.

Alas, the Dao of Heaven and Earth—
Deep and distant, subtle and refined—
Few can recognize it,
Fewer still can follow it.
Wisdom and insight cannot grasp it,
Only the babe embodies it.

The babe’s nature mirrors virtue—
The babe knows yet does not speak,
Understands yet does not reveal,
Has power yet does not act,
Is skilled yet remains hidden—
Alive yet like death,
Fresh yet like decay—
Acting without action,
Matching the Dao in every detail.

Life that is not life,
A body that is not a body,
Use that is not use,
Hearing that is not hearing—
Without action or affairs,
Without intention or heart,
Not seeking virtue or spirit,
Not accumulating wisdom—
Neither thinking nor pondering,
Nor obstructed by barriers—
Their spirit does not stir,
Their clarity knows no bounds,
Soft yet void, still yet tranquil,
Their souls are at peace.

Joy without seeking joy,
Ease without desiring ease—
They live without wasting their spirit,
They die without lingering regrets.

Thus they can be enveloped by the Dao and contain virtue,
Align with Heaven and Earth—
Then bees and wasps, venomous creatures and snakes,
Will have no will to inflict their stings.
Raptors and fierce beasts
Will have no intent to seize or attack.

Venomous creatures do not sting,
Raptors do not clutch—
Because there is no place for death.
Bones frail, sinews soft,
Yet their grasp is firm and unyielding.
They see not male and female,
Yet Yin and Yang transform them.

Their spirit is full and complete,
All beings unite with them—
Their cries do not grow hoarse,
Their harmony can be called perfect.
Their actions and deeds
Align with the eternal Dao.

To know harmony is to know the eternal.
To hold fast and guard it
Is to be wise and enlightened—
To know the eternal is to be clear.

By nature, they flourish and grow—
When they move, all blessings gather.
Their hearts act in profound mystery,
Their *qi* flows, robust and unyielding—
The heart directs the *qi*, and this is called *strength*—
Without striving, they overcome all.

chunks.original_text: 无所欲，故动无所丧。 自然通达，众美萌生，天地爱佑，祸乱素亡。 夫何故哉？ 以含德和神，而体童蒙也。 及其有知也，去一而之二，去晦而之明，身日饰而德日消，智逾多而迷益深。 故重天下而轻其神，贵名势而贱其身，深思远虑，离散精神，背柔弃弱，力进坚刚，陷於欲得，溺於求生，开於危殆，塞於万全。 物壮则老。 故福如天地，视而不能见； 祸若雷霆，听而不能闻。 出无入有，日造祸殃。 谓之非道。 动而之穷，为而之亡，修身爱国，为国不祥。 祭燎而天地是伐，祷祀而鬼神是丧，非命之罪，事物自当也。 身既违道，祸则自来，非天命有所与夺，故云非道早已。 知者不言章 知者不言不能专，言者不知道亡身。
chunks.translated_text:
Without desire, their movements lose nothing.
Naturally open and free, all virtues sprout anew—
Heaven and Earth shower their favor,
While calamity and chaos fade away.

Yet why is this so?
Because they embrace virtue and harmony of spirit,
And preserve the innocence of youth.

When knowledge dawns, they abandon unity for duality,
Discard obscurity for clarity—
Their bodies adorned, their virtue erodes,
The more they know, the deeper their confusion grows.

Thus, they prize the world yet neglect their spirit,
Value fame and power yet scorn their own bodies,
Overthink and overplan, scattering their spirit’s essence,
Rejecting softness, abandoning weakness,
Forcing progress toward rigidity,
Falling into greed, drowning in the pursuit of life,
Opening themselves to peril while blocking all safety.

When strength peaks, decay begins.
Thus, blessings as vast as Heaven and Earth—
You see them yet cannot grasp them;
Disaster strikes like thunder—
You hear it yet cannot avoid it.

They give without receiving,
Daily inviting ruin.
This is called *not aligning with the Dao*.

Act and you reach exhaustion,
Strive and you court destruction—
Cultivating the self, loving the nation,
Yet such devotion brings misfortune.

Offer sacrifices, and Heaven and Earth turn against you;
Pray to spirits, and the gods abandon you.
No fault of fate—
The consequences of actions unfold as they must.

The wise do not speak of their virtue—
The wise do not speak lest they lose focus,
Those who speak do not know—
And lose their lives.
